item.title: Spies, Burgers and Bombs: After a New War, Old Wounds Resurface in Tehran
item.description: A deep sense of unease has gripped Iran since American and Israeli airstrikes in June, but on a recent visit to the capital, we found that many Iranians seemed to be just trying to get by.

item.title: L.A. County Declares State of Emergency Over Immigration Raids
item.description: The move would allow county officials to provide financial aid to those affected by Immigration and Customs Enforcement raids.

item.title: A Repressive Russian Ally Feels a Mysterious Thaw From the U.S.
item.description: Analysts say they are unsure what the Trump administration hopes to get out of its gifts and concessions to Belarus’s autocratic leader.

item.title: Putin Welcomes Syria’s New President in Moscow, While Still Harboring al-Assad
item.description: The meeting in Moscow between President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and President Ahmed al-Shara of Syria showcased the adaptability of two leaders once at odds.

item.title: London Became a Global Hub for Phone Theft. Now We Know Why.
item.description: About 80,000 phones were stolen in the British capital last year. The police are finally discovering where many of them went.

item.title: Clashes Between Afghanistan and Pakistan Kill at Least 12
item.description: The fighting, along the countries’ border, also injured more than 100 people. Tensions have sharply escalated over the past week. Both sides accused the other of striking first.

item.title: Raila Odinga, Former Kenyan Prime Minister and Champion of Democracy, Dies at 80
item.description: A pivotal political leader who helped usher in multiparty democracy in the East African country, he ran unsuccessfully for the presidency five times.

item.title: How the U.S. and the Arab World Teamed Up to Seal the Gaza Deal
item.description: The cease-fire talks in Egypt showed that with pressure on Hamas and Israel, seemingly huge impediments could be overcome or set aside.

item.title: South Korea Targets Cambodia’s Scam Industry After Kidnaps, Torture and a Death
item.description: South Korea’s efforts are part of a widening international crackdown on criminal groups running online fraud schemes from Southeast Asia.

item.title: First Burials to Be Held for Israelis Returned From Gaza
item.description: Hamas has handed over the bodies of eight people, but says it is struggling to find the remains of others in Gaza after two years of war.

item.title: Syria’s New Leaders Are Talking to Russia, a Former Enemy
item.description: President Ahmed al-Shara is making his first trip to Moscow, which backed the regime his rebels overthrew. Both sides have reasons to put the past aside.

item.title: As U.S. Warships Patrol Caribbean, Drug Smugglers Shift Tactics
item.description: With the United States surging its military presence in the region and bombing boats, countries in the Caribbean are seeing more flights carrying illegal drugs.

item.title: Trump’s Tariff Fight With China Means Trouble for a Vast Wilderness in Brazil
item.description: Brazilian farmers are lobbying to roll back deforestation restrictions in order to sell more soybeans to the huge Chinese market.

item.title: ‘Promises Have Not Been Kept’: What’s Behind Africa’s Youth Protests
item.description: Protesters say their anger reflects a lack of economic opportunity on a continent with the world’s youngest population.

item.title: A Photographer Captures Jewish Life Before and After the Holocaust
item.description: Edward Serotta created an archive of 1,230 in-depth interviews with Holocaust survivors about how they lived, both before and after. “Every one of them comes with a story,” he said.

item.title: Inside Iran’s Museum of American Espionage
item.description: The enduring animosity between the United States and Iran is reflected inside the walls of the former U.S. embassy in Tehran, now turned into a museum of anti-American propaganda. U.S. involvement in the June Iran-Israel war has resurfaced that shared past.

item.title: What Makes a Martyr?
item.description: Since his death, Charlie Kirk has become a powerful symbol for the far right.

item.title: China Wants Foreign Scientists. The Public Says No, Thanks.
item.description: Since Beijing announced a new visa to attract young science and technology graduates, a backlash has erupted online, forcing the government to respond.

item.title: Inmates Make Brazen Escape in Guatemala
item.description: “I’m not going to deny the reality — there’s no good explanation,” the interior minister said of how the 20 inmates had slipped out, perhaps over a period of time.

item.title: Trump Dangles $20 Billion Lifeline for Argentina, With Strings Attached
item.description: President Trump said the economic support is contingent on whether his political ally, President Javier Milei of Argentina, remains in power.

item.title: Israel Pressures Hamas to Return Bodies, but Gaza’s Destruction Poses Challenge
item.description: The Israeli government is considering limits on aid to Gaza to penalize Hamas for not turning over more bodies of former hostages. But devastation in the enclave complicates the retrieval of all remains.

item.title: Madagascar Rejoices After Military Takeover and Impeachment
item.description: The change in power came after Parliament voted to impeach President Andry Rajoelina, who faced mounting pressure after weeks of Gen Z protests.

item.title: What to Know About the Protests in Madagascar
item.description: President Andry Rajoelina appears to have left the country after weeks of protests calling for him to resign.

item.title: Russia Accuses Antiwar Exiles of Terrorism
item.description: An intelligence agency’s sweeping investigation shows that Moscow is closely following the anti-Kremlin activities of Russians abroad.

item.title: Cuban Dissident Leader Leaves Prison for Exile in the U.S.
item.description: José Daniel Ferrer said long periods in solitary confinement left him feeling buried alive. Secretary of State Marco Rubio welcomed his arrival in Miami.

item.title: Trump Calls for Israel’s President to Pardon Netanyahu. Could It Happen?
item.description: The Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, has been on trial for corruption since 2020, battling charges of bribery, fraud and breach of trust in three separate but related cases.

item.title: Madagascar’s President Goes Into Hiding
item.description: The move followed weeks of intense and deadly protests against the government of President Andry Rajoelina, who said he would defy growing calls to resign.

item.title: Ukraine’s Formula for Peace: Fewer Talks, More Weapons
item.description: As Russia rebuffs President Trump’s diplomatic push, President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine plans to head again to the White House, this time seeking missiles.

item.title: Zelensky Revokes Odesa Mayor’s Citizenship, Amid Feud With Local Leaders
item.description: Ukraine’s security services said the mayor held Russian citizenship, which is forbidden, but he denied the accusation. Government opponents see it as part of a power grab.

item.title: Why Was the President of FIFA at the Gaza Summit?
item.description: Gianni Infantino, the head of soccer’s global governing body, frequently appears alongside President Trump at events outside the realm of sports.

item.title: French Premier Offers to Delay Pension Overhaul, in a Bid to Calm Turmoil
item.description: Sébastien Lecornu said the government was ready for “a new debate” on the issue, a major concession as he faces no-confidence votes that threaten to topple his government again this week.

item.title: Bangladesh Garment Factory Fire Kills at Least 16, Official Says
item.description: The death toll was expected to climb from the blaze, which also included a nearby chemicals warehouse.

item.title: Newsom Vetoes California’s Ban on ‘Forever Chemicals’ in Cookware
item.description: Mr. Newsom said he was concerned that the measure restricting PFAS chemicals would make pots and pans more expensive for Californians.

item.title: How Trump’s Gaza Peace Plan Presents Hurdles for Israel and Hamas
item.description: Hamas released hostages and agreed to abide by a cease-fire, but persuading it to lay down its arms is another matter.

item.title: To Meet Pledges to Save Forests Spending Must Triple, U.N. Report Says
item.description: Four years after a global pledge to end deforestation, the amount of money going toward conserving and restoring forests is not enough, the analysis found.

item.title: Dozens Are Dead and Dozens More Missing as Catastrophic Rains Devastate Mexico
item.description: Torrential rains set off deadly floods and landslides across five Mexican states, leaving a trail of destruction.

item.title: Explosion at Italian Farmhouse Kills Three Military Police Officers
item.description: The police were carrying out a search warrant at a home whose occupants were resisting eviction, officials said. More than a dozen officers were injured.

item.title: Protests in Brussels Halt Flights and Disrupt Public Transit
item.description: The demonstrations, organized by Belgium’s major trade unions, oppose austerity proposals that would affect pensions and other social welfare.

item.title: Venezuela Closes Embassy in Norway After Activist Receives Peace Prize
item.description: The announcement came three days after María Corina Machado, an opposition leader, was awarded the Nobel Peace Prize.

item.title: Trump Takes a Victory Lap, but Avoids Questions About What’s Next
item.description: Except for brief references, President Trump did not talk about what it would take to rebuild Gaza or about the future of the Palestinian people.

item.title: A Reality Check on Peace
item.description: We talk to our Jerusalem bureau chief, David Halbfinger, about what comes after the cease-fire deal in Gaza.

item.title: Trump’s Two Minds on China Sow a Chaotic Few Days
item.description: The president’s bellicose vow of steep new tariffs, followed quickly by a more conciliatory message, pointed to an internal tug of war over his approach.

item.title: A Divided Israel Unites in Joy as Hostages Come Home
item.description: With the release from Gaza of the last surviving captives, many Israelis said it was time for the country to heal after years of polarizing war.

item.title: Trump Touts ‘Very Important Signing,’ but Details Are Few
item.description: The document from a summit in Egypt left many questions unanswered.

item.title: Palestinians See Little to Celebrate Even Though the Bombs Have Stopped
item.description: The cease-fire in Gaza has taken hold. Hostages and prisoners have been exchanged. But amid the utter devastation of two years of war, a sense of gloom pervades.

item.title: Trump and Abbas Share Moment of Rapprochement in Egypt
item.description: The Palestinian leader was recently denied a U.S. visa, preventing him from going to the United Nations last month to witness the recognition of a Palestinian state by several nations.

item.title: As Hostages and Prisoners Return Home, Trump Declares ‘New Dawn’ in Mideast
item.description: With Hamas freeing the last 20 living Israeli hostages and Israel releasing some 2,000 Palestinian prisoners, President Trump proclaimed an ‘end’ to the war, but big questions about Gaza’s future remain.

item.title: Some Israeli families are anguished to see the release of Palestinians convicted of killing their loved ones.
The Release of Israeli Hostages and Palestinian Prisoners in Photos and Videos
item.description: Twenty living hostages were freed by Hamas on Monday under the cease-fire deal, and Israel released nearly 2,000 Palestinian prisoners.

item.title: 2 Men Charged After Ian Watkins, Former Lostprophets Singer, Is Killed in Prison
item.description: Mr. Watkins had been serving a 29-year sentence for child sex abuse offenses at the Wakefield Prison in northern England.

item.title: What Are the Abraham Accords, Trump’s 2020 Mideast Deals?
item.description: The diplomatic deals that opened ties between Israel and several Arab countries were hailed as a landmark moment, but have failed to bring peace to the Middle East.

item.title: W.H.O. Warns of Sharp Increase in Drug-Resistant Infections
item.description: The U.N. health agency found that one in six infections worldwide was resistant to the most commonly available antibiotics.

item.title: Macron Urges Stability Despite Calls for Government Ouster in France
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron of France is facing some of the country’s worst political turmoil in decades. A new government has been appointed, but how long it will last is anyone’s guess.

item.title: More Than 40 People Killed in Bus Crash in South Africa
item.description: The bus was carrying passengers from Zimbabwe and Malawi who were traveling back to their home countries.

item.title: Arab Leaders Brace for Tough Negotiations at Egypt Summit
item.description: The meeting in Sharm el-Sheikh, Egypt, could expedite an end to the Gaza war, but regional powers must still resolve the thorny details that have stymied negotiations.

item.title: Gazans confront a devastating reality: ‘There’s nothing to be happy about.’
